abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Natural Resources
            Management Project for Tunisia were as follows: outcome was
            moderately unsatisfactory, risk to development outcome was
            significant, Bank performance was moderately satisfactory,
            and Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: weaknesses in the structures that
            are used to integrate communities into the development
            process can undermine securing genuine collaboration of
            communities over the long term. It is important that
            community organizations have sufficient legal standing to
            ensure their legitimacy in representing the
            communities' priorities to government agencies, that
            communities view the leaders of such organizations as
            legitimate, and that all segments of the population are
            represented. Demonstrating the effectiveness of natural
            resource management interventions requires attention to
            monitoring and evaluation of actual outcomes. Measuring
            actual results is not only important for understanding
            whether the intended development impact has been achieved,
            but also for assessing the cost effectiveness of the
            measures supported and generating information on what needs
            to be improved. Effective promotion of income-generating
            projects requires more than support for production.

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, with substantial
            institutional development impacts, supported by satisfactory
            Bank and Borrower performances. The first important lesson
            in designing an integrated rural development type of
            project, is that start-up will be slow due to the need to
            carefully prepare local development plans in close
            collaboration with the beneficiaries. Consequently, a
            project preparation phase would be desirable, during which
            institutional coordination units could be established, and
            the required training, mainly for an integrated
            participatory approach (IPA), provided. A second lesson is
            that projects with complex institutional frameworks require
            effective monitoring and evaluation systems, which should be
            comprehensive and operationally sound, contain quantifiable
            impact and output indicators, as well as physical and
            financial achievement indicators, in order to be effective
            project management tools. Third, it is necessary to address
            simultaneously local private needs for productive
            investments and public needs for socio-economic investments
            in order to create the income and wealth necessary to
            maintain the public investments. Both types of investments
            need to be accompanied by public and/or private training and
            advice to achieve their full potential. Finally, since
            integrated rural development projects normally combine soft
            investments (technical assistance and training), with hard
            investments (physical works at the field level), the
            assistance of other co-financiers with different terms and
            conditions is often required. This can be risky, especially
            when co-financing affects the project's key activities.
            In such cases, the project financing plan must be well
            designed, with co-financiers willing to fulfill their
            commitments, and in addition, remedial measures must be anticipated.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Natural Resources
            Management Project are sustainable natural resources
            management, in particular of crop and range land in severely
            degraded zones, and agricultural productivity improvements,
            attained with greater involvement of resource users in
            development programs. The main project components are two.
            First, the Natural Resources Management Operations component
            comprises two sub-components: (a) the project will finance
            Participatory Development Plans (PDP) prepared by local
            communities, assisted by the Regional Agricultural
            Development Offices (CRDA) technical staff, to address their
            priorities for soil and water conservation, agricultural and
            pastoral development, small-scale irrigation systems and
            other rural infrastructure, and women's support
            activities; and (b) the project will finance erosion control
            and water recharge investments in the three related
            CRDA's, mainly on public lands, as part of the
            government's national soil and water conservation
            strategy, to protect the areas where a participatory
            approach will be tested. The second component, Institutional
            Strengthening, at both the CRDA and central levels, will
            support Ministry of Agriculture human resources and
            information systems development, and adjust the incentive
            framework for sustainable resources management.
